Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Relativistic Particle Precipitation and Upper Atmospheric Effects
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will examine how energetic particle precipitation affects the electrical conductivity and fields in the upper and middle atmosphere. It will examine how solar energetic protons access the middle atmosphere and will utilize the gamma rays emitted by the incoming protons to determine the energy spectrum of the incoming particles. It will also investigate the mechanisms which accelerate, transport, and precipitate relativistic electrons.

The project will analyze data from two balloon data sets that contain multiple episodes of energetic particle precipitation. Models will be constructed to describe the effects these energetic particles produce in the upper and middle atmosphere. Model results will be compared with measured middle atmosphere radiation, conductivity, and electric fields. To determine the mechanisms which accelerate, transport and precipitate relativistic electrons the balloon observations will be combined with ground and spacecraft observations to test wave-particle interaction theories for precipitation.

The results from the project will improve our ability to predict energetic precipitation events that can affect a variety of satellites and can alter the chemical composition of the atmosphere. The project is a collaborative one involving faculty and students at Dartmouth College, the University of Washington and the University of Houston.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the major goals of this project was to compare spacecraft and balloon observations in order to test wave-particle theories for electron precipitation. "Electrons Precipitation" refers to the atmospheric loss of particles from Earth's Van Allen radiation Belts. Electron loss is an important controlling factor for Earth's radiation belts, yet the causes are still unknown. For this project, data were analyzed from two previous Antarctic balloon campaigns that detected precipitation: the MAXIS experiment in January 2000 and the MINIS experiment in January 2005. The results were compared with  spacecraft and ground-based observations during the same interval. Specifically, we

1.) Compared precipitation observations from the NOAA POES satellites MEPED instrument with data from the MAXIS balloon experiment to better characterize the energy and spatial distributions of precipitation; 
2.) Examined the relationship of precipitation to the plasmapause location using data from IMAGE EUV (during MINIS balloon flights) and a model of the plasmapause (during MAXIS); 
3.) Examined data from the Polar and GOES spacecraft to look for electromagnetic ion cyclotron (EMIC) waves during the observed precipitation events; 
4.) Investigated the timing of precipitation during the January 21, 2005 event relative to the arrival of an interplanetary shock at different locations using riometer data from Halley Bay and SANAE and the LFM model of the magnetosphere; 
5.) Used Polar and GOES magnetic and electric field data along with Halley Bay riometer data to investigate the nature of observed ultra low frequency (ULF) modulation of precipitation. 

From this analysis, it was found that precipitation during the January 19, 2000 MAXIS event was only occurring at dusk and was observed in conjugate hemispheres. This implies that the process scattering the electrons is one that acts in the dusk sector. This is important because it tells us something about the nature of the mechanism acting. The precipitation was observed by the MAXIS balloon in a plasmaspheric plume, consistent with scattering by EMIC waves. However, the energy of precipitating particles extends down to several hundred keV, which is determined by both the POES and balloon observations. This is inconsistent with current models of EMIC scattering of electrons, thus remains a mystery. For this event, precipitation extended only to radial distances of about  5 earth radii, thus the depletion of the trapped population observed at geosynchronous orbit could not be attributed to precipitation (though precipitation does appear to be responsible for the drop at smaller radial distances. This is very important because it suggests that loss at larger distances from Earth is dominated by so-called magnetopause losses, whereby particles leave the magnetosphere and escape into the interplanetary medium.

For the January 21, 2005 MINIS event, a shock arrival led to ULF waves in the magnetosphere according to a LFM MHD model. The frequency of the ULF waves was very close to the ULF modulation observed in the precipitation. The model results indicate that the waves acted to violate the second adiabatic invariant of the particles, pushing some of them into the atmosphere. These results were important because they indicate a completely new mechanism that has never been considered before. 

This project has further advanced our understanding of electron losses in Earth's radiation belts. This is inconsistent with current models of EMIC scattering of electrons, thus remains a mystery. For this event, precipitation extended only to radial distances of about 5 earth radii, thus the depletion of the trapped population observed at geosynchronous orbit could not be attributed to precipitation (though precipitation does appear to be responsible for the drop at smaller radial distances. This is very important because it suggests that loss at larger distances from Earth is dominated by so-called magnetopause losses, whereby particles leave the magnetosphere and escape into the interplanetary medium. For the January 21, 2005 MINIS event, a shock arrival led to ULF waves in the magnetosphere according to a LFM MHD model. The frequency of the ULF waves was very close to the ULF modulation observed in the precipitation. The model results indicate that the waves acted to violate the second adiabatic invariant of the particles, pushing some of them into the atmosphere. These results were important because they indicate a completely new mechanism that has never been considered before. This project has further advanced our understanding of electron losses in Earth's radiation belts. Quantifying and understanding losses is critical for the development of radiation belt models that will ultimately be able to predict the radiation environment around Earth. Thus the practical application of this work is that it will help to improve models that are important for the design and operations of spacecraft in the near-Earth environment - an increasingly important part of our modern society.
